## Usage

* html, xml, pdf downloads, collected by publishers

```{r usage, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, comment=NA, cache=TRUE, echo=FALSE}
library(rplos); library(alm); library(plyr)
dois <- searchplos(terms="*:*", fields='id', limit=500,
   toquery=list('cross_published_journal_key:PLoSONE', 'doc_type:full', 
                'publication_date:[2010-01-01T00:00:00Z TO 2010-12-31T23:59:59Z]'))
out <- alm(doi=do.call(c,dois), total_details=TRUE)
outdf <- ldply(out)
```

```{r usageplot, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, comment=NA, cache=TRUE, fig.width=14, fig.height=6}
plot_density(outdf, source=c('counter_pdf','counter_html'), color=c("#DBAC6A", "#A06D34"), plot_type="histogram")
```

---

## Citation

* Scopus, PubMed Central, Crossref

```{r citationplot, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, comment=NA, cache=TRUE, fig.width=14, fig.height=6}
plot_density(outdf, source=c('crossref_citations','pubmed_citations','scopus_citations'), color=c("#EFA5A5","#CFD470","#B2C9E4"), plot_type="histogram")
```

---

## Social media

* Twitter, Mendeley, Facebook, etc., collected by altmetrics aggregators

```{r socialmediaplot, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, comment=NA, cache=TRUE, fig.width=14, fig.height=6}
plot_density(outdf, source=c('twitter_total','mendeley_total','facebook_total'), color=c("#EFA5A5","#CFD470","#B2C9E4"), plot_type="histogram")
```

## Anecdotes

>* Academics reporting altmetrics on their CV's and say that it *may* have helped them get tenure
>* Stories of use in hiring/tenure decisions - but no hard data (e.g., [this](http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/information-culture/2013/02/13/providing-context-for-the-metrics-used-to-evaluate-the-scientific-literature/))
>* Some have used altmetrics on their application to be an editor for <a href="#">PeerJ</a>
>* [Wellcome Trust](http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/) has been thinking about using for evaluations
>* [Amy Brand @ Harvard](http://www.faculty.harvard.edu/about-office/our-team) on evaluations - don't look at journal name; do look at citations - other products "leaking in"
>* [SSRN](http://www.ssrn.com/) - uses downloads as a metric for relative impact/use
>* Wikipedia mentions can be particularly interesting - *a textbook on the web*

## What I'm worried about

>* Data consistency: aggregators don't collect data in the same way, e.g., Twitter => ImpactStory (Topsy), Altmetric (Twitter API), PlumAnalytics (Topsy), PLOS ALM (??)
>* Data provenance: aggregators tracking this, but newcomers may not - some provenance we'll never know
>* Long-term sustainability: Web resources are ephemeral - how do we ensure data persistence?
>* Openness: 
	* open data
	* transparent calculations
